awd_titl_txt: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track B: Community-Based Research meets Systems Approach: Closing the Loop on Child Lead Poisoning
awd_abstract_narration:
Even in communities where lead (Pb) exposure pathways are well understood, there are significant barriers to getting resources to the most affected individuals. These disparities in access to healthcare lead to a generational disadvantage as the households that face lead poisoning are disproportionately composed of racial minorities that live in low-income neighborhoods. This CIVIC research is at the intersection of community-based research and technology-driven frameworks.  The goal of this research is to understand how to close communication gaps among households, healthcare providers, and policymakers. This has the potential to increase access to in-time health care, and enables quick and aggressive interventions via an app to be developed to tie all relevant parties together to improve the coordination of care to prevent child lead poisoning. The initial target community is St. Joseph County, Indiana. The research engages all relevant stakeholders in the process of lead poisoning diagnosis, intervention, and remediation/abatement. Broader impacts of the work include better health outcomes and less lead poisoning in children from low-income neighborhoods as well as engagement and training of engineering and chemistry undergraduate students. Students will be involved in developing accessible educational materials to inform households about the risks of lead exposure, especially in children, with the goal of helping community members identify and pursue lead assessment/abatement resources to protect the health of their loved ones. Student teams involved in the Stage 1 and follow-on Stage 2 program, if funded, will receive experiential learning opportunities and work with communities to translate community challenges into problem statements and help with the implementation of possible solutions. Research findings and developed technologies and informational materials will be scalable to other localities in the US and elsewhere with high soil and home lead concentrations.

Although Community-Based Participatory Research encourages multidisciplinary case review teams to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions, an understanding of the relationship between individual, community, provider, and system factors is presently underexplored. This prevents the critical insight necessary to create risk reduction strategies, improve clinical pathways, and eliminate barriers to care. Through the CIVIC Stage 1 planning period, an interdisciplinary and multi stakeholder group of community members, health providers, researchers, and policymakers will be convened to understand the targeted community and the overlapping roles and responsibilities that each group has in closing the loop of lead detection in children and connecting households to resources that provide abatement interventions. These design thinking sessions and discussions will inform a framework for deploying community health workers, who work directly with impacted communities, and provide informational and technological solutions in the form of an app which will be co-designed by the community and university researchers as part of the pilot project. In the following Stage 2 project, the app and identified solutions will be deployed and evaluated alongside the performance of a previously developed, low-cost, lead, screening kit through a pilot program. The techno-sociological framework will enable a greater understanding about if and how the voices of marginalized patients are being heard, understood, and acted upon. 

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track B. Bridging the gap between essential resources and services & community needs—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

Even in communities where lead (Pb) exposure pathways are well understood, there are significant barriers to getting resources to the most affected individuals. These disparities in access to healthcare drive generational disadvantages as the households that face lead poisoning are disproportionately composed of racial minorities that live in low-income neighborhoods. The goal of this research was to understand how to close communication and coordination gaps among households, healthcare providers, and policymakers in order to increase access to in-time health care. The initial target community for our study was St. Joseph County, Indiana, an area that was spotlighted in 2016 as having a higher percentage of children with elevated blood lead levels than Flint, Michigan did at the peak of their water contamination crisis.  Our team included several programs at the University of Notre Dame: Notre Dame Lead Innovation Team (ND-LIT), the Lucy Family Institute for Data & Society (LFIDS), and the Center for Civic Innovation, (CCI); Beacon Health System (Beacon); the St. Joseph County Department of Health (SJCDoH); City of South Bend; the Lead Affinity Group (LAG); and the Michiana Community Health Workers Coalition (MCHC). Through several convening events, we co-created the concept of a socio-technical system, namely LeadRx, to enable interventions close the loop through improved coordination.

 

Intellectual Merit:

We developed and strengthened a coalition of partnerships in this Stage 1 work to understand the distinct and overlapping roles of families, healthcare providers, and governmental organizations in lead poisoning prevention and case management. We explored the following questions in Stage 1 to identify both gaps and opportunities to inform the design and development of our socio-technical system, LeadRx. The Stage 1 explored answers to questions such as :What happens after the ND-LIT Screening Kit detects lead in a house? What happens after a blood test reveals elevated lead levels in a child? What interventions can be provided to the families to halt or lessen the negative impacts of lead? How does (or should) the County Health Department keep a pulse on latest data for reporting and action? How to facilitate hand-off between screening and diagnosis? How do families receive support for lead remediation? How can we make it easier for both property owners and tenants to work with the City government to receive grants for lead remediation? How do we keep families aware, engaged, and educated?

The team led over six in-person convening meetings, which were hosted in collaboration with LAG and the South Bend Near Northwest Neighborhood organization. These monthly meetings, kick-off, and closing symposia allowed for researchers, CHWs, parents, healthcare providers, and policymakers to expand on the barriers identified in the survey and provided the opportunity for new stakeholders to identify additional barriers, including: a lack of trained contractors to complete the time-intensive process of home lead remediation, inconsistency between physicians in messaging to families about the risks of their child’s blood lead levels, patients not returning for follow-up visits, and a severe lack of available, lead-free housing in the event that a tenant is evicted for requesting lead interventions from their landlord.

At these meetings, we also led participatory design thinking sessions about how to best use data and technology to overcome the gaps through the mobile application (LeadRx) of the socio-technical platform intended for use by CHWs while they are directly interacting with families and providing case management services. LeadRx can be used by community healthcare workers (CHWs) to transmit information to parents, empower households to access existing lead detection and prevention tools, facilitate communication between parents and their care providing team (CHWs, OB-GYN, and pediatrician), and to enable a peer-to-peer coordination network between CHWs that are employed by different healthcare organizations.

 

Broader Impacts:

The socio-technical solution, realized through LeadRx, addresses the three gaps: sharing knowledge and awareness about available resources (consistent educational materials and lists with up-to-date contact information), communication with patients about the status of their test results and next steps, and coordination (hand-off) between organizations. The findings and interventions from our work are anticipated to be scalable and can be employed in other counties to prevent child lead poisoning. Additionally, an interdisciplinary team of three undergraduate students and one high school student conducted interviews with key stakeholders about the hazards of lead poisoning. These interviews informed students in their development of educational and awareness materials to inform households about the risks of lead exposure, especially in children, with the goal of helping community members identify and pursue lead assessment/abatement resources to protect the health of their loved ones. Materials were created in accessible formats in both English and Spanish.

 


Last Modified: 01/08/2024
Modified by: Nitesh Chawla

Images (1 of )
  • Schematic for closing the loop of child lead poisoning through LeadRx. Coordinated by CHWs using LeadRx, a child (family) may enter the loop from either ND-LIT screening and/or blood test at the healthcare provider, which then activates eligibility for remediation services (e.g. grants) provided by
    University of Notre Dame
    Copyrighted
    Nitesh Chawla
    LeadRX
  • Community stakeholders at a convening Stage 1 Workshop provided feedback on LeadRx design and brainstormed about increasing lead resource coordination.
    University of Notre Dame
    Copyrighted
    Nitesh Chawla
    Meeting
